iati-activity.iati-identifier: MZ-MOJ-100717344-Prevention of Conflicts in Mozambique 2019 Elections

title.narrative: Prevention of Conflicts in Mozambique 2019 Elections

description.narrative: During the implemetation the following activities have been successfully carried out: The 3 activities (Trainings of key actors in the resolution of electoral contents, Monitoring and observation of the electoral process, Advocacy for the reinforcement of the legal component of electoral content resolution) had as target groups the various political and electoral actors, namely: electoral observers, political parties, electoral management and administration bodies and civil society, where the common objective of the interventions was to contribute to more peaceful, fair and conflict-free elections. This was achieved through: (i) training of election observers who were allocated to the Electoral Observation Platform - “Peace Room”; (ii) monitoring and observation of the voting process in the 6 provinces elected for observation: Nampula, Zambezia, Sofala, Manica, Tete and Gaza. Thus, for the purpose of communicating to the actors, incidents / occurrences for immediate intervention by the respective organs, the “Peace Room”, coordinated by IMD, issued 3 communiqués during the voting day. As is well known, Mozambican electoral processes are cyclically stained by episodes of violence and it is in this context that advocacy actions have been developed for conflict prevention and resolution. Such interventions were characterized by appeals and recommendations to actors for socially and politically acceptable and dignified conduct.
The political actors (Political parties and coalitions) , electoral bodies, Justice Institutions and others interest groups and voters.

The project goals were met: • Trainings of key actors in the resolution of electoral contents; • Monitoring and observation of the electoral process • Advocacy for the reinforcement of the legal component of electoral content resolution.

The project was more focused on the practical component and implementation of the tools elaborated in the first phase. In this sense, the project was following the entire election campaign, voting day, counting of results, as well as the dissemination of partial results. In this regard, the IDM continued to gather elements for advocacy in the next revision of the electoral legislation. The election campaign ran with high levels of violence. On the one hand, electoral violence and, on the other, non-electoral violence. It was also evident that the provinces of Nampula, Zambezia, Tete, Gaza and Niassa remained the most violent during the campaign period. IMD as coordinator of the “Peace Room” considers that the incidents that occurred in the election campaign were motivated by: (i) Political intolerance, which still characterizes democratic coexistence in Mozambique. (ii) Some non-compliance with basic road safety measures, as well as where large numbers of members and supporters of political parties gather. (iii) Some perception of impunity and lack of accountability to violators of the law, and (iv) Lack of preparation and guidance of campaigners regarding electoral legislation and elementary issues such as where campaign materials may or may not be fixed.
